body: @junichi11 thank you for the confirmation. I think the second error is more cosmetical and I found the problem. Could you please test with this PR whether it fixes the issues you are seeing?
hey @mvorisek is this somehow a templating engine that you use? Is it handlebars or what is it?

I can also reproduce it on the `api.service.js`. Is looked like an error in the file but when I open the Action Items to see what errors NetBeans shows me, it is this strange error: 

`Error | class com.oracle.js.parser.ParserContextModuleNode cannot be cast to class com.oracle.js.parser.Pars |`

> hey @mvorisek is this somehow a templating engine that you use? Is it handlebars or what is it?

Hey Chris, thank you for follow up.

See https://github.com/atk4/ui/tree/3.1.0/template , we use `{$class}` and `{_class}{/}` in our templating engine https://github.com/atk4/ui/blob/3.1.0/src/HtmlTemplate.php#L491 .

The issue we have is that when we use such templating, the files are marked red in the whole project tree which disctracts every developer who uses Netbeans.

As the tags we use do not violate the html grammar (as pointed by Matthias above, only the style/CSS grammar is incorrect), I belive such html templates should be parsed successfully and the minor issues should be a line warnings instead, so the file itself is not marked red.

As said: You can turn off CSS checking. (for a file, or a whole directory tree). But disabling in directly will yield a bug with a text: "Hey! This is an IDE why don't you even get basic syntax checking right?!!!!1". For you it is a minor details, for others it is just broken.

The Web decided not to go down the well defined way. With XHTML I have some ideas how you could sanely define a template language, but with the maschup that is HTML today, you have to guess. In the end the IDE would need  a crystal ball to decide, whether the author made a syntax error or if it is a template. I saw authors write curly braces into style attributes and they thought they used correct syntax, so no curly braces are not an indicator for the begin of a template.

There are other things in the HTML code, that could be better fixed, that this case, where two usescases (normal HTML editing vs. templating) collide hard.
@Chris2011 could you please provide the full text - it should be available in the IDE log.
@matthiasblaesing I can't get those logs with this change and a PHP project now. PHP features seem to work correctly. Thanks!

This is related to https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/3296

The problem occurs here:
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/aa1f69f3fb50defdda5aab682275d35be49557fa/ide/csl.api/src/org/netbeans/modules/csl/navigation/ElementNode.java#L245

We don't expect that `StructureItem.getElementHandle()` returns `null`.
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/aa1f69f3fb50defdda5aab682275d35be49557fa/ide/csl.api/src/org/netbeans/modules/csl/api/StructureItem.java#L36

However, `TopLevelStructureItem.getElementHandle()` returns `null`.
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/aa1f69f3fb50defdda5aab682275d35be49557fa/ide/css.editor/src/org/netbeans/modules/css/editor/module/main/TopLevelStructureItem.java#L52-L55

@matthiasblaesing Could you please have a look at this?

@lkishalmi you don't need to open an issue if there's a PR ready - keeps the signal-to-noise ratio down a bit. And if you're a committer, you can remove the `needs:triage` yourself and/or open a ticket via the meta form too.

@neilcsmith-net Just rebased on delivery. Take this if you wish. It seems I need to take a few strolls on the shores of the Pacific Ocean (wife orders), so I won't be around for a while.

Hey @matthiasblaesing unfortunately, it is not shown in the IDE log. I restarted NetBeans too to check whether I accidentally removed it but no. It just shows in the Actions Items and not in the notifications. Maybe running the master of NetBeans in debug mode and if NetBeans can handle this "pause on exception" that can help here.

So I checked VS Code and WebStorm and both also shows this as errors. As Matthias said, I also think, this is ok. If the toolkit, that you use have a language service like the Angular Language Service, that there could be a better solution to parse the file and and and but I guess that this is not available. What WebStorm does is just a better error label for each error: With this errors I can understand the error better. NetBeans just show smth from the original parser which is not very friendly if I have no clue about tokens, parser, etc. But this is a whole other topic and not related to this here. It was just an information.
@matthiasblaesing Thank you for fixing it!
I got it now and needed to use the debugger to get the full message. The issue can only be hit when javascript module parsing takes place. I think I have that solved.
Thanks @lkishalmi - and enjoy your strolls!

Hey @mbien , thanks! I was unsure about the new process..

This is not a bug in NetBeans:

a) 12.5 is not the current versinon of NetBeans
b) the issue is reported from a plugin module (com.jaspersoft.irport)
c) It is invalid to access the `com.sun.image.codec.jpeg` package. It is not even in the JDK and even if so would be private API.

Please contact the plugin author.

I can confirm, that the parser bails out when parsing the construct (even when not embedded into HTML).

13 is already in the process to being released and only open for release critical fixes, this is not a regression and CSS for print is not the main use-case. Sorry, but this feature won't be supported in 13. If anyone wants to look at this for 14, the right place to start is `ide/css.lib`. The grammar is in the `Css3.g` file in the `org.netbeans.modules.css.lib` package. After changing the grammar, the lexer and parser have to be regenerated (see the `build.xml` of that module for that).

A trivial test is:

```java
    public void testX() {
        assertParses(" @page {\n" +
"                @top-center {\n" +
"                    content: element(top);\n" +
"                }\n" +
"                @bottom-center {\n" +
"                    content: element(bottom);\n" +
"                }\n" +
"            }", true);
    }
```
The change seems to cause more serious side effects on other test cases than this indent. Can you also confirm that ?

Well, I've no more say than anyone else what goes in NB13!  However, I do have reservations about dropping this in so late.  I'm also curious what the implications are with things like Compile on Save?  Hard fail with workaround in NB13, and aiming to look at a better experience for this in NB14 seems a good move to me.
Thanks @mbien - merging!

The changes in 12.6 _were_ about moving to Gradle being better supported. The project wizard changed to use `gradle init` in #3084 so that's why you see the different structure to before. I think there could be an option to enable single project structure - feel free to open a feature request on that one.

I cannot reproduce your rename issues.  Given other problems, and that you're using JDK 17, have you migrated settings from earlier versions of NetBeans? If so, check what your default Gradle version is in Tools / Options. Have noticed an issue with older versions carried forward that don't support JDK 17.
I cannot reproduce this. Please check the question about default Gradle version in #3595
Do you have ClearType enabled?  Can you reproduce in a basic Swing application?  I suspect this is a JDK issue.

@jlahoda could you please have a look at this? The change itself is IMHO dead-simple and sane.  Yet the unittests fail.

To me it seems, that the testing infrastructure makes assumptions, that don't hold anymore. My gut feeling is, that having the language available on the document being worked on, causes additional helpers to kick in, that change the behavior of the test. I also have the feeling, that you might directly know what is going on here.

PHP 8.1 support is already tracked at https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-5599
Part of it is already implemented and will be included in upcoming NetBeans 13.

I rechecked the grammar - it already supports the syntax, errors are generated from the CSS verifier. The CSS Generated Content module was extended by the element function, which is not yet supported.

Just for the record: The CSS specification around the "content" property is a mess. 

[CSS Generated Content for Paged Media Module](https://www.w3.org/TR/css-gcpm-3/) at least partially contradicts/extends [CSS Generated Content Module Level 3](https://www.w3.org/TR/css-content-3).

It turned out that the reason for `findClassUsages()` not returning any hits was `maven-indexer`producing [lower case based queries](https://github.com/apache/maven-indexer/blob/d8cb9841aa6fd24cbf5f8f5614c27c56c300e97e/indexer-core/src/main/java/org/apache/maven/index/context/NexusAnalyzer.java#L50-L58), while `ClassDependencyIndexCreator` encodes class dependencies in searchable Base64 encoded CRC32 Strings (-> case sensitive). This worked for some reason with old lucene (maybe searches were case insensitive?) but fails now after the lucene upgrade, since there is an asymmetry between the tokenizing phase and the query phase.

But even if it worked before, it is likely still a bug since it could produce false positives if I see this correctly. In any case a big part of the Base64 key space is wasted.

The hack [587084e](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/3558/commits/587084eb504b61bb32a5a7abaa53498f7bc9348b) simulates the old behavior and lets all tests pass locally.

potential fix: encode with Base32 instead (in lowercase, but this would be 7 chars (1 char longer) or find other solution preferably via lucene, unfortunately maven-indexer has it's NexusAnalyzer hard coded.
There is no error reported.

We use this as part of a template to be processed by:
https://www.thymeleaf.org
and
https://github.com/danfickle/openhtmltopdf

Unfortunately I did not find enough precise information of the '''--no-rebuild''' flag. According to this: https://github.com/gradle/gradle/issues/3077 that shall be deprecated in Gradle 4.4, then removed. Yet Gradle 7.4 still have that option.
@mklaehn wait please. If you want do do this for all/most modules, do multiple modules per PR. Maybe a cluster per PR if possible. Travis has already a full queue right now.

@mklaehn split it into commits, this allows reviewing just as if it would be split into PRs. Keep in mind that every PR is basically 2h of testing for the CI cluster, twice. NB has ~20 top level folders. Using one PR per top level folder would be too disruptive just for cosmetics IMO.

Quoting:
_Not following this convention has no technical impact, but will reduce the codes readability because most developers are used to the standard order._
I apologize having to say that I don't see any enhancement in code's readability with these commits.

According to @entlicher the reason for the failed test `DebugAllBaseTest`  is most probably already in the master, not in this PR. See for example https://app.travis-ci.com/github/apache/netbeans/builds/246681735 which is failing with the same message.
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-6458 was filled for the suspected cause, but not fixed yet.

Merging.

regarding the timeout of `NBMNativeMWITest`
The junit tests expected the query to fail with a NPE in the indexer code
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/c084119009d2e0f736f225d706bc1827af283501/apisupport/maven.apisupport/src/org/netbeans/modules/maven/apisupport/MavenNbModuleImpl.java#L145-L149

post migration, the NPE does not occur. The query appears to work. However, this causes the download+indexing of the maven central repo. Which causes a timeout after 3 minutes.

So my question is: was the test originally supposed to download the index?

NPE suppression was added here: 57e21b8

changelog: https://github.com/apache/felix-dev/blob/master/framework/doc/changelog.txt
It's surprising this was reported as a missing library.

I added a missing "//NOI18N" marker and will merge when Unittests come back.

The reason for the missing library report is, that all namespace mappings are expected to be JSF libraries. What was overlooked is, that there might be a reason to declare a schema location (in our case the XHTML namespace is referenced). Other might map other normal XML namespaces, but I wanted to keep this minimal and a straight forward fix.
@matthiasblaesing , sorry for delays. I'll take a look to see if I can find out what is going on.

@matthiasblaesing Yep. In the future I think we should have a list of most used namespaces in the web we should be skipping (say SVG). 

Note that is you skip the XML Schema namespace you may be wanting to skip XLink as well, which is a common companion of XML Schema.

@fcorneli please have a look at the PR #3642. It does not fix all issues, but should make parsing of the contents of @page declarations more stable. There is still no support for "content: element(...)", but at least to parse now works and you just get warnings.

If you need a prebuild binary, you can download it here: https://doppel-helix.eu/NetBeans-dev-dev-293093d9e96fa3d0bcfb238a5d16228138678062-release.zip

I intent to merge this by mid next week. If anyone wants to object, please do so. The changesets to the parse itself can be found here:

https://github.com/matthiasblaesing/graaljs-nb

dev_cache/mavenindex 161 items, totalling 4,3 GB

Solved in https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/3644
I added another condition to the script to try to handle the DPI scaling case described by Michal Hlavac in https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-2360 , on openSUSE Tumbleweed.

> Where's the upstream notice file coming from? Wasn't able to find it.

For Apache Projects I would always look first in the JAR itself. You can't be required to include a NOTICE you don't have. There are two main places to look: 

- the root of the JAR
- the META-INF folder

If that fails, I would look into the repository of the project (but if a project does not follow its own rules, this might already be to much).

> Also, untested, since this is only a minor bugfix update.

I changes behavior in classloaders and using Unsafe. Two notoriously incompatible places. Changes without checks are bad. Always. At least a manual check has to be done.
@BradWalker  please don't merge PRs without giving others a chance to review - even if it seems trivial.
@mbien , sorry about that.. I got a little bit aggressive with this.. My sincere apologies.. I'll get it fixed..

Hey @mbien , can you look at this and tell me if it meets with your approval. My apologies for being a little bit aggressive with my previous commit. Two years of removing rust from Netbeans, I was bound to eventually make a mistake. My apologies!

@BradWalker no worries, looks good. I would have removed the empty lines between the cases but it doesn't really matter

I was more worried about a possible NPE and tried to investigate while you pressed merge at the same time :). But looking at the original code in NB again, vmName can't be null (and if it was it would have caused a NPE before too). False alarm.

Also feel free to aggregate multiple similar changes under one PR in future (if you know in advance that there will be more), this puts less load on the CI cluster (one PR is 2x~2h of cluster time) and also produces less noise in the commit history. 
NB has a big codebase. Its better to bundle similar cleanup changesets - if reasonably possible (similar discussion here https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/3624 - this would have been 20 PRs). And please don't misunderstand, if you only have time for one package - thats perfectly fine, put it into a PR.
Thanks @mbien!!
